channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Vaccine specialist Peter Hotez: scientists are ‘under attack for someone else’s political gain’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02981-z

The physician-researcher who spoke out against misinformation during the COVID-19 pandemic says attacks against science are formidable — and getting worse.
item.dc:title: Vaccine specialist Peter Hotez: scientists are ‘under attack for someone else’s political gain’
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogorodzki

item.title: Global effects of marine protected areas on food security are unknown
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06493-8

Global effects of marine protected areas on food security are unknown
item.dc:title: Global effects of marine protected areas on food security are unknown
item.dc:creator: Daniel Ovando
Owen Liu
Renato Molina
Ana Parma
Cody Szuwalski

item.title: For Health Equity, Location Matters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02612-7

A special package explores problems and solutions to the geography of injustice.
item.dc:title: For Health Equity, Location Matters
item.dc:creator: Lauren Gravitz

item.title: Furry little creatures teem with a multitude of viruses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02917-7

Large-scale survey reveals the diversity of viruses in small mammals, which can be sources of viruses that hop to humans.
item.dc:title: Furry little creatures teem with a multitude of viruses

item.title: World recommits to 2030 plan to save humanity — despite falling short so far
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02970-2

United Nations secretary-general António Guterres proposes US$500 billion annual stimulus package to meet the Sustainable Development Goals.
item.dc:title: World recommits to 2030 plan to save humanity — despite falling short so far
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: A crystalline doubly oxidized carbene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06539-x

The synthesis and isolation of a crystalline dication derived from a bis(imino)carbene through a two-electron oxidation/oxide-ion abstraction strategy is reported that bypasses the carbene radical cation, maintaining significant electrophilicity with two accessible vacant orbitals.
item.dc:title: A crystalline doubly oxidized carbene
item.dc:creator: Ying Kai Loh
Mohand Melaimi
Milan Gembicky
Dominik Munz
Guy Bertrand

item.title: Reply to: Global effects of marine protected areas on food security are unknown
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06494-7

Reply to: Global effects of marine protected areas on food security are unknown
item.dc:title: Reply to: Global effects of marine protected areas on food security are unknown

item.title: Geminal-atom catalysis for cross-coupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06529-z

Heterogeneous geminal-atom catalysts, which pair single-atom sites in specific coordination and spatial proximity, offer a new avenue for the sustainable manufacture of fine chemicals.
item.dc:title: Geminal-atom catalysis for cross-coupling
item.dc:creator: Xiao Hai

item.title: The contribution of wildfire to PM<sub>2.5</sub> trends in the USA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06522-6

Ground- and satellite-based air pollution data from 2000 to 2022 quantify the contribution of wildfire smoke to stagnation or reversal in PM2.5 concentration trends, showing that this contribution will grow as the climate continues to warm.
item.dc:title: The contribution of wildfire to PM<sub>2.5</sub> trends in the USA
item.dc:creator: Marshall Burke
Marissa L. Childs
Brandon de la Cuesta
Minghao Qiu
Jessica Li
Carlos F. Gould
Sam Heft-Neal
Michael Wara

item.title: Cingulate dynamics track depression recovery with deep brain stimulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06541-3

This study demonstrates how activity in the cingulate cortex tracks depression recovery, providing symptom relief using deep brain stimulation.
item.dc:title: Cingulate dynamics track depression recovery with deep brain stimulation
item.dc:creator: Sankaraleengam Alagapan
Ki Sueng Choi
Stephen Heisig

item.title: Reductive carboxylation epigenetically instructs T cell differentiation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06546-y

Reductive carboxylation of glutamine by isocitrate dehydrogenase 2 (IDH2) has a role in determining the fate of T cells, and inhibiting this enzyme promotes the differentiation of memory T cells.
item.dc:title: Reductive carboxylation epigenetically instructs T cell differentiation
item.dc:creator: Alison Jaccard
Tania Wyss
Noelia Maldonado-Pérez
Jan A. Rath
Alessio Bevilacqua

Mathias Wenes

item.title: Global population exposure to landscape fire air pollution from 2000 to 2019
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06398-6

The global population is increasingly exposed to daily landscape fire-sourced air pollution but there are socioeconomic disparities, with this pollution four times higher in low-income countries than in high-income countries during the period 2000–2019.
item.dc:title: Global population exposure to landscape fire air pollution from 2000 to 2019
item.dc:creator: Rongbin Xu
Tingting Ye
Xu Yue
Zhengyu Yang

item.title: Multistable sheets with rewritable patterns for switchable shape-morphing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06353-5

To demonstrate the power of multistability, a specific class of groovy metasheets is introduced as a new shape-morphing platform that allows repeated switching from the flat state to multiple, precisely selected and stable three-dimensional shapes.
item.dc:title: Multistable sheets with rewritable patterns for switchable shape-morphing
item.dc:creator: A. S. Meeussen
M. van Hecke

item.title: Acetyl-methyllysine marks chromatin at active transcription start sites
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06565-9

Cellular lysine residues can be both methylated and acetylated on the same sidechain to form Nε-acetyl-Nε-methyllysine (Kacme), which is found on histone H4 across a range of species and across mammalian tissues and is associated with active chromatin.
item.dc:title: Acetyl-methyllysine marks chromatin at active transcription start sites
item.dc:creator: William J. Lu-Culligan
Leah J. Connor
Yixuan Xie
Babatunde E. Ekundayo
Brendan T. Rose

Benjamin A. Garcia

Matthew D. Simon

item.title: Cryo-EM structures reveal native GABA<sub>A</sub> receptor assemblies and pharmacology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06556-w

Using cryo-EM, structures of three major assemblies of type A GABA receptors, which regulate brain excitability, are revealed in the mouse brain and provide a basis for the development of subtype-specific drugs.
item.dc:title: Cryo-EM structures reveal native GABA<sub>A</sub> receptor assemblies and pharmacology
item.dc:creator: Chang Sun
Hongtao Zhu
Sarah Clark
Eric Gouaux

item.title: Synthesis of portimines reveals the basis of their anti-cancer activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06535-1

A scalable total synthesis of portimines enables structural reassignment of portimine B and in-depth functional evaluation of portimine A, revealing that portimine A induces translation inhibition selectively in human cancer cells and is efficacious in vivo tumour-clearance models.
item.dc:title: Synthesis of portimines reveals the basis of their anti-cancer activity
item.dc:creator: Junchen Tang
Weichao Li
Tzu-Yuan Chiu
Francisco Martínez-Peña
Zengwei Luo

Nathalia Gazaniga

Yi Yang See
Luke L. Lairson
Christopher G. Parker
Phil S. Baran

item.title: Transgenic ferret models define pulmonary ionocyte diversity and function
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06549-9

Conditional genetic ferret models enable ionocyte lineage tracing, ionocyte ablation and ionocyte-specific deletion of CFTR to elucidate the roles of pulmonary ionocyte biology and function during human health and disease.
item.dc:title: Transgenic ferret models define pulmonary ionocyte diversity and function
item.dc:creator: Feng Yuan

item.title: The β<sub>1</sub>-adrenergic receptor links sympathetic nerves to T cell exhaustion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06568-6

Stress-associated catecholamines promote CD8+ T cell exhaustion through the β1-adrenergic receptor, and blocking β-adrenergic signalling may help restore anti-tumour functions.
item.dc:title: The β<sub>1</sub>-adrenergic receptor links sympathetic nerves to T cell exhaustion
item.dc:creator: Anna-Maria Globig
Steven Zhao
Jessica Roginsky
Vivien I. Maltez

item.title: Transcriptional linkage analysis with in vivo AAV-Perturb-seq
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06570-y

An in vivo single-cell CRISPR screening method identifies transcriptional phenotypes of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome associated with a broad dysregulation of a class of disease susceptibility genes that are important for RNA processing and synaptic function.
item.dc:title: Transcriptional linkage analysis with in vivo AAV-Perturb-seq
item.dc:creator: Antonio J. Santinha
Esther Klingler
Maria Kuhn
Rick Farouni
Sandra Lagler
Georgios Kalamakis
Ulrike Lischetti
Denis Jabaudon
Randall J. Platt

item.title: A multi-stem cell basis for craniosynostosis and calvarial mineralization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06526-2

The calvarial stem cell niche is populated by a cathepsin K-expressing cell lineage and a newly identified discoidin domain-containing receptor 2-expressing lineage, both of which are required for proper calvarial mineralization.
item.dc:title: A multi-stem cell basis for craniosynostosis and calvarial mineralization
item.dc:creator: Seoyeon Bok
Alisha R. Yallowitz

item.title: Global iron and steel plant CO<sub>2</sub> emissions and carbon-neutrality pathways
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06486-7

A CO2 emissions inventory of 4,883 individual iron and steel plants along with their technical characteristics is described, allowing the identification and guidance of the most appropriate emissions mitigation and decarbonization pathways for each plant.
item.dc:title: Global iron and steel plant CO<sub>2</sub> emissions and carbon-neutrality pathways
item.dc:creator: Tianyang Lei
Daoping Wang
Xiang Yu
Shijun Ma
Weichen Zhao
Can Cui
Jing Meng
Shu Tao
Dabo Guan

item.title: The oldest three-dimensionally preserved vertebrate neurocranium
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06538-y

Computed tomography reveals that the cranial anatomy of Ordovician stem-group gnathostome Eriptychius americanus from the Harding Sandstone of Colorado, USA, is distinct among vertebrates.
item.dc:title: The oldest three-dimensionally preserved vertebrate neurocranium
item.dc:creator: Richard P. Dearden
Agnese Lanzetti
Sam Giles
Zerina Johanson
Andy S. Jones
Stephan Lautenschlager
Emma Randle
Ivan J. Sansom

item.title: Neural circuitry for maternal oxytocin release induced by infant cries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06540-4

Experiments in mice identify a neural circuit that relays information about infant cries from the maternal auditory thalamus to hypothalamic oxytocin neurons to induce the release of oxytocin and modulate maternal behaviour.
item.dc:title: Neural circuitry for maternal oxytocin release induced by infant cries
item.dc:creator: Silvana Valtcheva
Habon A. Issa
Chloe J. Bair-Marshall
Kathleen A. Martin
Kanghoon Jung
Yiyao Zhang
Hyung-Bae Kwon
Robert C. Froemke

item.title: Evidence for the earliest structural use of wood at least 476,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06557-9

Wooden artefacts from waterlogged deposits in Zambia dating back 477 ka indicate hitherto unknown sophistication in woodworking at an early date.
item.dc:title: Evidence for the earliest structural use of wood at least 476,000 years ago
item.dc:creator: L. Barham
G. A. T. Duller
I. Candy
C. Scott
C. R. Cartwright

item.title: Wildfires are worsening air quality in the United States
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02794-0

Air-pollution data from pollution-monitoring stations and satellites show that wildfire smoke has influenced trends in levels of fine particulate matter in nearly three-quarters of the contiguous United States, undoing around 25% of air-quality improvements made between 2000 and 2016. Wildfires are likely to further erode air quality in the country as the climate warms.
item.dc:title: Wildfires are worsening air quality in the United States

item.title: Hominins built with wood 476,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02858-1

Understanding the timeline of technological developments sheds light on early societies. A remarkable finding in Africa of a structure made from shaped wood provides clues about our hominin relatives.
item.dc:title: Hominins built with wood 476,000 years ago
item.dc:creator: Annemieke Milks

item.title: People Who Are Changing the Environment One Community at a Time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02615-4

These four researchers are highlighting environmental inequities and improving the health of their communities.
item.dc:title: People Who Are Changing the Environment One Community at a Time
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: Getting inside the oldest known vertebrate skull
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02865-2

Analysis of a 458-million-year-old fossil fish reveals anatomical insights about the vertebrate skull and how skull organization evolved from that of ancestral early vertebrates to that of jawed vertebrates.
item.dc:title: Getting inside the oldest known vertebrate skull
item.dc:creator: Zhikun Gai
Philip C. J. Donoghue

item.title: Consciousness theory slammed as ‘pseudoscience’ — sparking uproar
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02971-1

Researchers publicly call out theory that they say is not well supported by science, but that gets undue attention.
item.dc:title: Consciousness theory slammed as ‘pseudoscience’ — sparking uproar
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Discrimination Has Trapped People of Color in Unhealthy Urban ‘Heat Islands’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02618-1

People of color, more than other groups, live in neighborhoods prone to excess heat and the illnesses that go with it.
item.dc:title: Discrimination Has Trapped People of Color in Unhealthy Urban ‘Heat Islands’
item.dc:creator: Melba Newsome

item.title: Dual stem-cell populations interact in the skull
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02547-z

The discovery that the skull has two groups of stem cell that produce similar types of descendant cell has big implications for the field of stem-cell research — and casts light on a developmental disorder that affects many children.
item.dc:title: Dual stem-cell populations interact in the skull
item.dc:creator: Andrei S. Chagin
Dana Trompet

item.title: ‘They went to the bar at noon’: what this virtual AI village is teaching researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02818-9

Researcher Joon Park talks about making a small town of AI-powered agents open-source.
item.dc:title: ‘They went to the bar at noon’: what this virtual AI village is teaching researchers

item.title: The neural circuit that makes maternal mice respond to pups’ cries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02545-1

All newborn mammals cry. The neural circuit that stimulates mothers to look after crying offspring has been identified in mice — along with a mechanism that promotes maternal behaviour only after prolonged calls from pups.
item.dc:title: The neural circuit that makes maternal mice respond to pups’ cries
item.dc:creator: Flavia Ricciardi
Cristina Márquez

item.title: Sympathetic nerves suppress T-cell responses in infection and in cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02776-2

T cells that are chronically stimulated in viral infection or cancer enter a dysfunctional state known as T-cell exhaustion. Sympathetic nerves in tissues and tumours drive T-cell exhaustion through the action of the neurotransmitter noradrenaline on the β1-adrenergic receptors of T cells, with implications for cancer treatment.
item.dc:title: Sympathetic nerves suppress T-cell responses in infection and in cancer

item.title: The Father of Environmental Justice Exposes the Geography of Inequity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02613-6

Robert Bullard reflects on the movement he created.
item.dc:title: The Father of Environmental Justice Exposes the Geography of Inequity
item.dc:creator: Yessenia Funes

item.title: Nipah virus outbreak: what scientists know so far
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02967-x

India is taking urgent steps to halt the transmission of a rare but deadly virus that spreads from bats to humans.
item.dc:title: Nipah virus outbreak: what scientists know so far
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: The chemical synthesis and anti-cancer properties of portimines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02788-y

The natural toxins portimine A and B have attracted interest for their unusual chemical architecture and potent anti-cancer activity. The first total synthesis of portimines enables the identification of portimine A’s molecular target and reveals that the toxin induces programmed cell death in human cancer cells.
item.dc:title: The chemical synthesis and anti-cancer properties of portimines

item.title: How worlds are born: JWST reveals exotic chemistry of planetary nurseries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02922-w

The telescope is delivering a cascade of insights about the ‘protoplanetary’ disks where planets take shape.
item.dc:title: How worlds are born: JWST reveals exotic chemistry of planetary nurseries
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Valley Fever Is a Growing Fungal Threat to Outdoor Workers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02616-3

The disease hits farmworkers and outdoor laborers disproportionately hard.
item.dc:title: Valley Fever Is a Growing Fungal Threat to Outdoor Workers
item.dc:creator: Ashli Blow

item.title: Rich countries must align science funding with the SDGs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02847-4

Research in poorer countries maps closely with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals — wealthy nations must follow if the goals are to be met.
item.dc:title: Rich countries must align science funding with the SDGs

item.title: Changing old viticulture for all the right rieslings
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02974-y

Can the French wine industry, built on history and terroir, adapt fast enough to withstand climate change?
item.dc:title: Changing old viticulture for all the right rieslings
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: Using CRISPR to study gene function aids understanding of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02779-z

Most high-throughput assays to investigate the role of genes in disease involve in vitro cell models. Now a technology that targets CRISPR–Cas9 gene editing to specific cells in mice, and analyses transcriptional effects in single nuclei, has led to fresh insights into the genes involved in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.
item.dc:title: Using CRISPR to study gene function aids understanding of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome

item.title: Fixing Air Pollution Could Dramatically Improve Health Disparities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02614-5

The most marginalized people are breathing the most polluted air, and improving it could improve health equity worldwide.
item.dc:title: Fixing Air Pollution Could Dramatically Improve Health Disparities
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan

item.title: Would you still love me if I was a wormhole?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02666-7

Searching for certainty.
item.dc:title: Would you still love me if I was a wormhole?
item.dc:creator: Wendy Nikel

item.title: The UK’s post-Brexit EU science deal: a graphical guide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02883-0

Nature explores the United Kingdom and European Union’s research agreements, brokered through seven years of rollercoaster negotiations.
item.dc:title: The UK’s post-Brexit EU science deal: a graphical guide
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer
Katharine Sanderson
Nisha Gaind
Layal Liverpool
Miryam Naddaf
Emma Stoye

item.title: Why does cancer spread to the spine? Newly discovered stem cells might be the key
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02968-w

A stem cell vital for vertebral growth also drives spine metastases, and the use of MDMA in the treatment of PTSD.
item.dc:title: Why does cancer spread to the spine? Newly discovered stem cells might be the key
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: These ancient whittled logs could be the earliest known wooden structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02928-4

Stacked timbers dated to roughly 476,000 years ago show that ancient hominins worked with wood.
item.dc:title: These ancient whittled logs could be the earliest known wooden structure
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: More People Die From Venomous Snakebites Each Year Than Have Ever Died from Ebola
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02617-2

In low- and middle-income nations, snakebite envenoming is more deadly than almost any other neglected tropical disease.
item.dc:title: More People Die From Venomous Snakebites Each Year Than Have Ever Died from Ebola
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Japanese fund to create ‘Ivy League’ gives first award to just one university
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02867-0

A plan to create an elite group of institutes has surprised researchers as government makes Tohoku University the sole recipient of grant.
item.dc:title: Japanese fund to create ‘Ivy League’ gives first award to just one university
item.dc:creator: Anna Ikarashi

item.title: Genetic modification can improve crop yields — but stop overselling it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02895-w

With a changing climate and a growing population, the world increasingly needs more-productive and resilient crops. But improving them requires a knowledge of what actually works in the field.
item.dc:title: Genetic modification can improve crop yields — but stop overselling it

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02953-3

Genetic sequences from a museum specimen offer fresh clues about the physiology of thylacines, which went extinct in the 1930s.

The more people do their jobs from home, the more they cut their greenhouse-gas emissions.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02916-8

Genetic analysis shows that some stick insects that supposedly reproduce without sex are actually pairing off to have offspring.
item.dc:title: The secret sex lives of ‘celibate’ stick insects

item.title: My double life as a cell biologist and crime writer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02933-7

Achieving tenure enabled Frances Brodsky to focus on her research, write three novels and launch a journal.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02905-x

Safe delivery of samples from an asteroid on 24 September will be the start of a global scientific journey — but similar missions need support.

item.title: AlphaFold tool pinpoints protein mutations that cause disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02943-5

Researchers have adapted the AI network to search for genetic changes linked to ill health.
item.dc:title: AlphaFold tool pinpoints protein mutations that cause disease

item.title: AI can help to speed up drug discovery — but only if we give it the right data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02896-9

Artificial-intelligence tools that enable companies to share data about drug candidates while keeping sensitive information safe can unleash the potential of machine learning and cutting-edge lab techniques, for the common good.
item.dc:title: AI can help to speed up drug discovery — but only if we give it the right data
item.dc:creator: Marissa Mock
Suzanne Edavettal

item.title: FedEx for your cells: this biological delivery service could treat disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02906-w

Researchers want to know why cells produce tiny packages called vesicles — and whether these bundles could be used for therapy.
item.dc:title: FedEx for your cells: this biological delivery service could treat disease
item.dc:creator: Alison Abbott

item.title: Daily briefing: Alzheimer’s makes brain cells undergo ‘cellular suicide’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02965-z

Neurons experience programmed cell death in the presence of amyloid plaques — the first clue to how brain cells die in Alzheimer’s disease. Plus, an ancient jawbone hints at a new human species and how to chart an industry-career trajectory.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Alzheimer’s makes brain cells undergo ‘cellular suicide’
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Why the pandemic treaty risks becoming COVID-19 groundhog day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02904-y

Talks are stalling, but everyone benefits when the fruits of vaccine and drugs research are shared equitably.
item.dc:title: Why the pandemic treaty risks becoming COVID-19 groundhog day

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02836-7

Base editing, which makes specific changes to a cell’s genome, is put to the test in CAR-T-cell treatments for leukaemia.

item.title: World’s most powerful X-ray laser will ‘film’ chemical reactions in unprecedented detail
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02874-1

Upgraded laser in California will produce one million X-ray pulses per second to study ultrafast processes at the atomic level.
item.dc:title: World’s most powerful X-ray laser will ‘film’ chemical reactions in unprecedented detail

item.title: NIH upholds controversial plan to step up oversight of foreign collaborators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02923-9

The US biomedical agency tweaked its new policy after an outcry from researchers, but will forge ahead.
item.dc:title: NIH upholds controversial plan to step up oversight of foreign collaborators
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Geneticist J. Craig Venter: ‘I consider retirement tantamount to death’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02907-9

The human genome ‘maverick’ talks sequencing the ocean, setting up a health-screening company after checking his own genes — and why he has no plans to stop.
item.dc:title: Geneticist J. Craig Venter: ‘I consider retirement tantamount to death’
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Daily briefing: War and weather made Libya floods worse
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02940-8

How climate change intensified the death and devastation caused by Libya’s worst flooding ever. Plus, who is doing ‘gain of function’ research on pathogens and octopuses used in research could receive the same protections as monkeys.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: War and weather made Libya floods worse
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: A new human species? Mystery surrounds 300,000-year-old fossil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02924-8

A chinless jawbone from eastern China that displays both modern and archaic features could represent a new branch of the human family tree.
item.dc:title: A new human species? Mystery surrounds 300,000-year-old fossil
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Promotion pathways: how scientists can chart their industry career trajectory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02908-8

Confused about promotion opportunities after moving to industry? Here are some pointers.
item.dc:title: Promotion pathways: how scientists can chart their industry career trajectory
item.dc:creator: Sandeep Ravindran

item.title: Nickelates join the club of high-temperature superconductors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02857-2

A nickel-based compound has shown evidence of a superconducting state at a temperature of 80 kelvin. The material bridges a gap between other nickelates and a notable class of superconductor containing copper.
item.dc:title: Nickelates join the club of high-temperature superconductors
item.dc:creator: Matthias Hepting
